text.p: Computer Associates International Inc. said Tuesday its first-quarter earnings jumped a surprisingly big 30 percent on strong sales of its computer network management software.
Net income for the quarter ended June 30 rose to $155.8 million, or 42 cents a share, from $119.8 million, or 32 cents, in the same quarter a year ago.
Wall Street had expected Computer Associates, the third-largest independent software company, to earn 39 cents a share, according to First Call, which tracks such forecasts.
First-quarter revenue rose 12 percent to $890.7 million from $792.1 million on strong sales of network management software, the company said.

Computer Associates, based in Islandia, N.Y., writes business software that runs on IBM mainframe computers. The company also writes software that simplifies the management of giant corporate computer networks.
Sales of its network management products, or client-server products, jumped 51 percent in the quarter, accounting for 40 percent of the company's total sales, it said.
Operations in Europe, a weak spot in recent quarters, also improved, it said.
Computer Associates's stock rose $1.44 to $64.31 on the New York Stock Exchange.
